title: Data Scientists vs Statisticians
text:
Below are my answers to the data science vs statistics questions.


I typically think of a data scientist as an individual that handles the programming required to manage a large amount of data. I imagine them as some type of contracter or consultant for another company.


There is a large overlap between the fields of data science and statistics. Both groups use the same programming languages and analyze data. However, in data science there is a greater emphasis on programming, while in statistics there is greater emphasis on the underlying mathematical principles.


As a statistics student, I identify more as a statistician, given the courses I have taken in statistical theory. However, the technology associated with the field of data science allows for so much analysis to be done on such a large scale that most statisticians probably consider themselves somewhat of a data scientist, and vice versa.

title: Data Scientists vs Statisticians
text:
Iris Data Set
As instructed, we create the object y from the Iris data set.
We determine the class, type, and structure of y.

y <- density(iris$Petal.Width)
class(y)

[1] "density"

typeof(y)

[1] "list"

str(y)

List of 7
 $ x        : num [1:512] -0.656 -0.648 -0.64 -0.633 -0.625 ...
 $ y        : num [1:512] 0.00163 0.0018 0.00199 0.00219 0.00241 ...
 $ bw       : num 0.252
 $ n        : int 150
 $ call     : language density.default(x = iris$Petal.Width)
 $ data.name: chr "iris$Petal.Width"
 $ has.na   : logi FALSE
 - attr(*, "class")= chr "density"


We plot the y and use echo:false to keep the R code from being displayed in the document rendered.





The echo: false option disables the printing of code (only output is displayed).
